conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on each segment of the equilateral triangular conductor frame due to the magnetic field.
The frame is an equilateral triangle, so each side has the same length and resistance.
The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the triangle.
The current flows from point A to point B through the triangle.

premise: The current flows from A to B, passing through the triangle.
conclusion: The current flows through segments AC and CB.

The force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field is given by F = I · L · B · sin(θ), where I is the current, L is the length of the conductor, B is the magnetic field strength, and θ is the angle between the current and the magnetic field.

premise: For segment AB, the force is F (given).
conclusion: The force on segment AB is F.

premise: For segments AC and CB, the current is split equally between them, so the current through each is I/2.
conclusion: The current through segments AC and CB is I/2.
The length of each segment is the same, L.
The angle between the current and the magnetic field is 90 degrees for all segments, so sin(90°) = 1.

premise: The force on segment AC is (I/2) · L · B.
conclusion: The force on segment AC is F/2.

premise: The force on segment CB is (I/2) · L · B.
conclusion: The force on segment CB is F/2.
The force on segment AB is perpendicular to the plane of the triangle, directed out of the plane.
The forces on segments AC and CB are also perpendicular to the plane of the triangle, but they are directed into the plane.

premise: The forces on segments AC and CB are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction, so they cancel each other out.
conclusion: The only force that contributes to the resultant is the force on segment AB, which is F.

premise: The force on AB is F and the forces on AC and CB are F/2 each, with the same direction.
conclusion: The magnitude of the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires is 1.5F.
